STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: Now I'll select treatments based on current clinical guidelines. - First-line treatment per guidelines: Supportive management with artificial tears, cold compresses, and patient education. - Supporting evidence: Viral conjunctivitis is self-limited; symptomatic relief enhances comfort and prevents secondary bacterial infection. - Patient-specific considerations: The patient’s age, recent activity, and behavioral history suggest no immunosuppression or complicating factors. - Contraindications or cautions: Avoid antibiotics unless bacterial superinfection suspected; prevent touching eyes to reduce autoinoculation.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: If medications are appropriate, I'll select based on efficacy and safety. - Primary medication choice: Topical antiviral is not indicated unless herpetic keratoconjunctivitis is suspected. Since the diagnosis is viral conjunctivitis of typical form, no antiviral required. - Rationale for selection: Symptomatic treatment is sufficient; antiviral agents are reserved for herpetic ocular infections. - Expected timeline for improvement: Symptoms typically improve within 7-14 days. - Key side effects to monitor: No medications required, but advise monitoring for worsening symptoms. - Alternative medications if first-line fails: Consider topical corticosteroids only if significant inflammation persists under specialist supervision.  STEP 4 - NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: I'll include lifestyle and behavioral interventions that enhance outcomes. - Primary non-drug interventions: Maintain eye hygiene, avoid touching or rubbing eyes, wash hands frequently. - Patient education priorities: Emphasize contagious nature, hygiene measures, and when to seek care. - Lifestyle modifications: Avoid swimming or sharing towels; minimize eye contact with others. - Behavioral interventions: Reinforce hand hygiene, reduce eyelid rubbing.  STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: I'll establish appropriate monitoring and follow-up care. - Follow-up timeline: Reassess in 3-7 days if symptoms persist or worsen. - Monitoring parameters: Severity of redness, discharge, visual changes, pain. - Red flag symptoms: Sudden vision loss, intense pain, photophobia, or signs of corneal involvement warrant immediate evaluation. - Treatment response assessment: Symptom improvement within 1 week; no worsening signs.
